wxAGG: wxWidgets and the Anti-Grain Geometry Renderer

wxAGG is a simple example showing one way to combine the cross-platform user interface library wxWidgets with the vector Anti-Grain Geometry (AGG) renderer. The interesting class is AGGWindow, a wxWindow that stores a bitmap (in the native format of your platform) and directs AGG to render directly into the bitmap. This bitmap is then used to paint the window when requested by the rest of the wxWidgets framework. The source should hopefully be self-explanatory.

License

This code was written by Adrian Secord and is placed in the public domain. I can't provide support, but I would like to hear of problems. You can contact me by email, or using the usual tools.

Building

Two integrated development environment setups are included in the ide directory: one for Apple's XCode 2.x environment and one for Microsoft's Visual Studio .NET 2003 environment (also known as version 7). The Visual Studio setup should also work in later versions. A Unix-style makefile is not provided but should be trivial to create.

The code has the two obvious dependencies: wxWidgets and AGG.

wxWidgets

The IDE setups assume that you have already installed wxWidgets in your environment in such a way that the compiler will find the headers, etc. without any special configuration. Under Windows you should install the wxWidget packages in C:\wxWidgets and make sure you can compile and run the included examples. Apple's OS X includes version 2.53 of wxWidgets pre-installed in /usr, so unless you need a later version, you do not need to do anything more. If you want to use another version of wxWidgets, you will need to modify the build settings to find the headers, the libraries, and, on OS X, check that the pre-processor defines emitted by the command wx-config --cppflags match those in the project settings.

wxAGG has been tested with wxWidgets versions 2.53 under OS X and 2.80 under Windows XP, but should work with most versions.

AGG

Since most users will not have AGG pre-installed, wxAGG expects to find the AGG source distribution in libraries/agg under the main wxAGG directory.

  1. Download an AGG source distribution from Anti-Grain's website.
  2. Unpack the package to into libraries.
  3. Rename the resulting directory (for example, agg-2.4) to be just agg.
  4. As a check, the file libraries/agg/readme should exist.
wxAGG has been tested with version 2.4 and 2.5, but should work with later versions. Note that the AGG license changed after version 2.4 from the LGPL to the GPL. If you use a later version that added or deleted files you will need to mirror these changes in the IDE project files.

If you already have the AGG source distribution stored elsewhere, then on Unix-like systems you can simply create a symbolic link under libraries called agg that points to the correct directory.
